issue.title: Max errors limit
issue.body:
When parsing large files, you can get thousands of errors - e.g. if you make a single mistake in the schema of a 10k lines CSV file.

Ideally we'd stop validation when the limit is reached and raise the validation error with one more error added "max errors of X reached".

If we can add this is V2 it would have to be off by default, in V3 we can set the default max errors to 500 or something.

comment.body: Has this been addressed since? (Similar feature in pandera https://github.com/unionai-oss/pandera/issues/2094)

Updates `flexsearch` from 0.7.43 to 0.8.205
Release notes

Sourced from flexsearch's releases.

v0.8.2

  • Config-Serialized Query Caches, Improved caching strategy for Document indexes and Resolver
  • Resolver Async Processing Workflow (including Queuing)
  • Extended Resolver Support: Worker, Persistent, Cache
  • Extended Result Highlighting: Boundaries, Ellipsis, Alignment
  • Improved TypeScript Typings
  • Improved Stemmer Handling
  • Improved Result Highlighting
  • Use multi-language charset normalization as the default Encoder
  • Simplified charset support for multi-language content
  • Charset renamed LatinExact => Exact, LatinDefault => Default and LatinSimple => Normalize, these are universal charset presets for any languages
  • Charset ArabicDefault and CyrillicDefault was removed, they are fully covered by the default universal charset presets
  • Charset Charset.CjkDefault was renamed to Charset.CJK

v0.8.1

  • Resolver Support for Documents
  • Asynchronous Runtime Balancer, new option priority
  • Export/Import Worker Indexes + Document Worker, new extern config options export and import
  • Improved interoperability of the different build packages, including source folder
  • Support custom filter function for encoder (stop-word filter)

v0.8.0

  • Persistent indexes support for: IndexedDB (Browser), Redis, SQLite, Postgres, MongoDB, Clickhouse
  • Enhanced language customization via the new Encoder class
  • Result Highlighting
  • Query performance achieve results up to 4.5 times faster compared to the previous generation v0.7.x by also improving the quality of results
  • Enhanced support for larger indexes or larger result sets
  • Improved offset and limit processing achieve up to 100 times faster traversal performance through large datasets
  • Support for larger In-Memory index with extended key size (the defaults maximum keystore limit is: 2^24)
  • Greatly enhanced performance of the whole text encoding pipeline
  • Improved indexing of numeric content (Triplets)
  • Intermediate result sets and Resolver
  • Basic Resolver: and, or, xor, not, limit, offset, boost, resolve
  • Improved charset collection
  • New charset preset soundex which further reduces memory consumption by also increasing "fuzziness"
  • Performance gain when polling tasks to the index by using "Event-Loop-Caches"
  • Up to 100 times faster deletion/replacement when not using the additional "fastupdate" register
  • Regex Pre-Compilation (transforms hundreds of regex rules into just a few)
  • Extended support for multiple tags (DocumentIndex)
  • Custom Fields ("Virtual Fields")
  • Custom Filter
  • Custom Score Function
  • Added French language preset (stop-word filter, stemmer)
  • Enhanced Worker Support
  • Export / Import index in chunks
  • Improved Build System + Bundler (Supported: CommonJS, ESM, Global Namespace), also the import of language packs are now supported for Node.js
  • Full covering index.d.ts type definitions
  • Fast-Boot Serialization optimized for Server-Side-Rendering (PHP, Python, Ruby, Rust, Java, Go, Node.js, ...)
Changelog

Sourced from flexsearch's changelog.

Changelog

Current Version

  • Calling index.clear() on a persistent Index does not stack to the task queue by default (which executes on commit), instead it will execute immediately and return a Promise
  • Added new tokenizer tolerant, inherits from strict but also matches simple typos like missing letters and swapped letters
  • Improved Redis Cleanup
  • Resolver: Support Result Highlighting

v0.8.2

  • Config-Serialized Query Caches, Improved caching strategy for Document indexes and Resolver
  • Resolver Async Processing Workflow (including Queuing)
  • Extended Resolver Support: Worker, Persistent, Cache
  • Extended Result Highlighting: Boundaries, Ellipsis, Alignment
  • Improved TypeScript Typings
  • Improved Stemmer Handling
  • Improved Result Highlighting
  • Use multi-language charset normalization as the default Encoder
  • Simplified charset support for multi-language content
  • Charset renamed LatinExact => Exact, LatinDefault => Default and LatinSimple => Normalize, these are universal charset presets for any languages
  • Charset ArabicDefault and CyrillicDefault was removed, they are fully covered by the default universal charset presets
  • Charset Charset.CjkDefault was renamed to Charset.CJK

v0.8.1

  • Resolver Support for Documents
  • Asynchronous Runtime Balancer, new option priority
  • Export/Import Worker Indexes + Document Worker, new extern config options export and import
  • Improved interoperability of the different build packages, including source folder
  • Support custom filter function for encoder (stop-word filter)

v0.8.0

  • Persistent indexes support for: IndexedDB (Browser), Redis, SQLite, Postgres, MongoDB, Clickhouse
  • Enhanced language customization via the new Encoder class
  • Result Highlighting
  • Query performance achieve results up to 4.5 times faster compared to the previous generation v0.7.x by also improving the quality of results
  • Enhanced support for larger indexes or larger result sets
  • Improved offset and limit processing achieve up to 100 times faster traversal performance through large datasets
  • Support for larger In-Memory index with extended key size (the defaults maximum keystore limit is: 2^24)
  • Greatly enhanced performance of the whole text encoding pipeline
  • Improved indexing of numeric content (Triplets)
  • Intermediate result sets and Resolver
  • Basic Resolver: and, or, xor, not, limit, offset, boost, resolve
  • Improved charset collection
  • New charset preset soundex which further reduces memory consumption by also increasing "fuzziness"
  • Performance gain when polling tasks to the index by using "Event-Loop-Caches"
  • Up to 100 times faster deletion/replacement when not using the additional "fastupdate" register
  • Regex Pre-Compilation (transforms hundreds of regex rules into just a few)

pull_request.title: ğŸ—ï¸ B2B Marketplace Foundation: Schema + Core Edge Functions
pull_request.body:
## ğŸš€ ZingLots B2B Marketplace Foundation

This PR transforms ZingLots from a collectibles auction platform to a **hyperlocal B2B surplus marketplace** focused on business equipment, construction materials, and commercial goods.

### ğŸ—ï¸ **Major Changes**

**Database Architecture**
- âœ… PostGIS integration for hyperlocal distance calculations
- âœ… B2B-focused schema with business verification tiers (T0-T3)
- âœ… Regions & locations for geographic market organization
- âœ… Enhanced escrow system with QR-based pickup verification
- âœ… Materialized views for high-performance browsing

**Core Edge Functions**
- âœ… `bids-place` - Radius validation + anti-snipe protection
- âœ… `connect-create-or-get` - Stripe Connect onboarding for sellers
- âœ… `payments-create-intent` - Winner payment with escrow setup
- âœ… `pickup-confirm` - QR scanning with automatic seller payout

**Key Features**
- ğŸ¯ **Hyperlocal Focus**: Distance-based bidding eligibility
- ğŸ¢ **B2B Verification Tiers**: Progressive access based on business verification
- ğŸ“ **Local Pickup Only**: No platform-arranged delivery
- â° **Soft-Close Anti-Snipe**: Auto-extends auctions for fair bidding
- ğŸ“± **QR Pickup System**: Secure handoff with instant seller payout

### ğŸ“Š **Business Model Transformation**

**From:** Live collectibles auctions (TCG, LEGO, etc.)
**To:** Always-on B2B surplus marketplace

**Target Verticals:**
- ğŸ—ï¸ Construction & Materials
- ğŸ½ï¸ Restaurant & Food Service  
- ğŸ¢ Office & Business Equipment
- ğŸ›ï¸ Municipal & Government Surplus

### ğŸš€ **Next Steps**

This foundation enables:
1. **Frontend Updates** - Region-based browsing, B2B lot creation forms
2. **AI Integration** - Listing assistance, pricing, moderation agents
3. **Mobile Apps** - QR scanner for pickup verification
4. **Analytics** - Regional marketplace health dashboards

### ğŸ“‹ **Migration Path**

1. Deploy SQL migrations in order (001 â†’ 050)
2. Deploy new Edge Functions
3. Update frontend to use new schema/APIs
4. Migrate existing data (if preserving any)

This implements **Tasks #4-8** from the comprehensive 25-task roadmap in the PRD documents.

---

**Ready for Review** ğŸ‰
Breaking changes are contained in new SQL files. Existing functionality preserved until frontend migration.

commits.message: Update or push file via API
a commit a day keeps your girlfriend away

Add isolation test for TOAST value reuse during CLUSTER

This test exercises the corner case in toast_save_datum() where CLUSTER
operations encounter duplicated TOAST references, reusing the existing
TOAST data instead of creating redundant copies.

During table rewrites like CLUSTER, both live and recently-dead versions
of a row may reference the same TOAST value.  When copying the second or
later version of such a row, the system checks if a TOAST value already
exists in the new TOAST table using toastrel_valueid_exists().  If
found, toast_save_datum() sets data_todo = 0 so as redundant data is not
stored, ensuring only one copy of the TOAST value exists in the new
table.

The test relies on a combination of UPDATE, CLUSTER, and checks of the
TOAST values used before and after the relation rewrite, to make sure
that the same values are reused across the rewrite.

This is a continuation of 69f75d671475 to make sure that this corner
case keeps working should we mess with this area of the code.

Author: Nikhil Kumar Veldanda <veldanda.nikhilkumar17@gmail.com>
Discussion: https://postgr.es/m/CAFAfj_E+kw5P713S8_jZyVgQAGVFfzFiTUJPrgo-TTtJJoazQw@mail.gmail.com

Update obsolete comments in ResultRelInfo struct.

Commit c5b7ba4e6 changed things so that the ri_RootResultRelInfo field
of this struct is set for both partitions and inheritance children and
used for tuple routing and transition capture (before that commit, it
was only set for partitions to route tuples into), but failed to update
these comments.

Author: Etsuro Fujita <etsuro.fujita@gmail.com>
Reviewed-by: Dean Rasheed <dean.a.rasheed@gmail.com>
Discussion: https://postgr.es/m/CAPmGK14NF5CcdCmTZpxrvpvBiT0y4EqKikW1r_wAu1CEHeOmUA%40mail.gmail.com
Backpatch-through: 14

Adding per backend commit and rollback counters

It relies on the existing per backend statistics that has been added in
9aea73fc61d. A new function is called in AtEOXact_PgStat() to increment those
two new counters.

Adding XID generation count per backend

This commit adds a new counter to record the number of XIDs generated per
backend. It will help to detect if a backend is consuming XIDs at a high rate.

Virtual transactions are not taken into account on purpose, we do want to track
only the XID where there is a risk of wraparound.

The counter is not part of PgStat_BackendPending, because we want to avoid
an extra function call in this code path to increment the counter in
PendingBackendStats. The counter increment here behaves more or less the same as
we do for WAL statistics.

Adding the pg_stat_backend view

This view displays one row per server process, showing statistics related to
the current activity of that process. It currently displays the pid, the
number of XIDs generated, the number of commits, the number of rollbacks and the
time at which these statistics were last reset.

It's built on top of a new function (pg_stat_get_backend_statistics()). The idea
is the same as pg_stat_activity and pg_stat_get_activity().

Adding documentation and tests.

issue.title: Makefile:775: arch/armv7l/Makefile: No such file or directory
issue.body:
Hi all,
Apologies is this is a very noob question. When trying to build this on RPI 2b with RTL8851BU adapter, I'm getting the following issue:

$make
make ARCH=armv7l CROSS_COMPILE= -C /lib/modules/6.1.21-v7+/build M=/home/pi/rtl8831  modules
make[1]: Entering directory '/usr/src/linux-headers-6.1.21-v7+'
Makefile:775: arch/armv7l/Makefile: No such file or directory
make[1]: *** No rule to make target 'arch/armv7l/Makefile'.  Stop.
make[1]: Leaving directory '/usr/src/linux-headers-6.1.21-v7+'
make: *** [Makefile:827: modules] Error 2


When I have created the directory and added the Makefile from the arm directory, the error becomes:

make ARCH=armv7l CROSS_COMPILE= -C /lib/modules/6.1.21-v7+/build M=/home/pi/rtl8831  modules
make[1]: Entering directory '/usr/src/linux-headers-6.1.21-v7+'
  CC [M]  /home/pi/rtl8831/platform/platform_ops.o
/home/pi/rtl8831/platform/platform_ops.c:15:10: fatal error: drv_types.h: No such file or directory
   15 | #include <drv_types.h>
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
make[2]: *** [scripts/Makefile.build:250: /home/pi/rtl8831/platform/platform_ops.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [Makefile:2012: /home/pi/rtl8831] Error 2
make[1]: Leaving directory '/usr/src/linux-headers-6.1.21-v7+'
make: *** [Makefile:827: modules] Error 2

Any help for armv7l users - seems like it's been an issue for other devs who have managed to implement something for non 64bit arm processors (https://github.com/diederikdehaas/rtl8812AU/issues/103)?
As a reasonably inexperienced user, I'm happy to try anything/provide more specific info if needed.

comment.body:
You can hardcode the include folder

I made a guide for this:
https://gitlab.waffly.xyz/waffle/realtek-rtl8831-rtl8851-driver

or you can follow this:
## ğŸš€ Installation Process

### Step 1: Clone the Repository

Download the RTL8831 driver source code:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/heesn/rtl8831.git
cd rtl8831
```

### Step 2: Add DKMS Module

Register the module with DKMS:

```bash
sudo dkms add .
```

### Step 3: Navigate to DKMS Directory

```bash
cd /usr/src/rtl8851bu-0.2
```

### Step 4: Configure Makefile Path

**Find the absolute path:**
```bash
cd ./include
pwd
# Note the output path (e.g., /usr/src/rtl8851bu-0.2/include)
cd ..
```

**Edit the Makefile:**
```bash
sudo nano Makefile
```

**Update this line:**
```makefile
# Change from:
EXTRA_CFLAGS += -I$(src)/include

# Change to (using your actual path):
EXTRA_CFLAGS += -I/usr/src/rtl8851bu-0.2/include
```

issue.title: mesa - fix GLX (fixes #331)
issue.body:
Fixes: https://github.com/Ravenports/ravensource/issues/331

Prior to this commit, glxinfo would report:

    ~ % glxinfo
    name of display: :0
    Error: couldn't find RGB GLX visual or fbconfig

unless mesa-libs from DPorts (DragonFly ports) were found on the system (pkg ins mesa-libs); chromium from DPorts for example depend on this lib.

ktracing "glxinfo" revealed that it is trying to load libGLX_mesa.so. But the latter is only build if libglvnd is found at build time, so this commit just adds libglvnd as a build-time dependency.

GLVND is the vendor neutral interface for GL.

With this commit in place, "glxinfo" properly works.

issue.title: Runtipi container in crash loop on Ubuntu 24.04 (Contabo VPS) with HestiaCP
issue.body:
Hello,

I'm trying to install Runtipi on a fresh server, but the container is stuck in a restart loop (`Restarting (1)`).

**My Environment:**
*   **OS:** Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
*   **Host:** Contabo VPS
*   **Co-existing Software:** HestiaCP (Nginx as reverse proxy)
*   **Docker Version:** `(mettez ici la sortie de la commande docker --version)`

**My `docker-compose.yml`:**
```yaml
version: "3.8"
services:
  runtipi:
    image: ghcr.io/runtipi/runtipi:latest
    container_name: runtipi
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "127.0.0.1:3000:3000"
    env_file:
      - .env
    volumes:
      - /home/admin/runtipi/data:/app/data
      - /home/admin/runtipi/apps:/app/apps
      - /home/admin/runtipi/backups:/app/backups
      - /home/admin/runtipi/compose:/app/compose
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
```

**My `.env` file:**
```
SERVER_HOSTNAME=localhost
SERVER_PORT=3000
SERVER_SCHEME=http
APPS_DIR=/app/apps
DATA_DIR=/app/data
BACKUPS_DIR=/app/backups
COMPOSE_DIR=/app/compose
ROOT_FOLDER_HOST=/home/admin/runtipi
```

**Docker Logs:**
The logs consistently show the following error:
```
[Nest] 18  - ... ERROR [ExceptionHandler] Error: unable to open database file
...
code: 'ERR_SQLITE_ERROR',
errcode: 14,
errstr: 'unable to open database file'
```

**Troubleshooting Steps Taken:**
*   Set permissions correctly with `sudo chown -R 1000:1000 ~/runtipi`.
*   The container **still crashes even when all volumes are commented out**, which suggests the problem is not a file permission issue on the host.

It seems there might be an incompatibility with the Ubuntu 24.04 environment or a bug in the latest image. Any help would be appreciated.

Thank you!

comment.body:
Hello,
Runtipi isn't just a docker compose with an env file you can start with `docker compose up`. It's managed by our [CLI](https://github.com/runtipi/cli) which handles creating the necessary folder structure and files and then actually starting the services.

Was the compose file AI generated? It's missing many services (and the one existing is completely wrong) and the environment variables you used do not exist. We provide actual [compose files](https://github.com/runtipi/runtipi/blob/develop/docker-compose.prod.yml) you could adapt and have documented our [environment variables](https://runtipi.io/docs/reference/environment-variables). Everything you need is documented and the code is easy enough to read to figure anything else out.

If you still want to try to use Runtipi with your custom setup (which I would not recommend _at all_, as it may not work and cause problems with exposing apps), please use the CLI and consider a [user-config](https://runtipi.io/docs/guides/customize-compose-and-traefik) that changes the ports traefik listens to (or keeps them available to the Docker internal network). You could then set up proxy rules from your proxy to traefik.

Honestly, it seems you do not have the knowledge required to configure this advanced setup and we cannot provide support for cases like these. Your options are probably the following:
- Remove your custom reverse proxy and use Runtipi as-is
- Install Runtipi _alone_ on a different VPS
- Consider a different self-hosting solution if Runtipi doesn't suit your needs. I doubt you'll find any easier to set up and more portable though.

issue.title: Phase 3: Workflow Automation Engine
issue.body:
## Overview
Build a powerful workflow automation engine with visual builder, extensive integrations, and template marketplace for automating complex multi-step processes.

## Technical Requirements

### Core Features
- **Visual Workflow Builder**
  - Drag-and-drop interface
  - Node-based flow design
  - Real-time preview
  - Conditional branching
  - Loop constructs
  - Error handling nodes

- **Trigger & Action System**
  - Time-based triggers
  - Event-based triggers
  - Webhook triggers
  - File system watchers
  - API endpoints
  - Manual triggers

- **Integration Framework**
  - REST API connector
  - GraphQL support
  - Database connectors
  - Cloud service integrations
  - Custom script nodes
  - External tool bridges

- **Template Marketplace**
  - Pre-built workflows
  - Industry templates
  - Custom template creation
  - Version control
  - Sharing mechanism
  - Rating system

### Technical Architecture
```typescript
interface Workflow {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  nodes: WorkflowNode[];
  edges: WorkflowEdge[];
  variables: Variable[];
  triggers: Trigger[];
  schedule: Schedule;
  errorHandling: ErrorStrategy;
}

interface WorkflowNode {
  id: string;
  type: 'action' | 'condition' | 'loop' | 'script' | 'integration';
  configuration: NodeConfig;
  inputs: Input[];
  outputs: Output[];
  errorHandler?: ErrorHandler;
}

interface AutomationEngine {
  executor: WorkflowExecutor;
  scheduler: JobScheduler;
  monitor: ExecutionMonitor;
  storage: WorkflowStorage;
  marketplace: TemplateMarketplace;
}
```

### Implementation Requirements
1. **Workflow Engine**
   - DAG execution engine
   - State management
   - Parallel execution
   - Retry mechanisms
   - Transaction support
   - Rollback capabilities

2. **Visual Builder**
   - React Flow or similar
   - Real-time validation
   - Syntax highlighting
   - Auto-layout algorithms
   - Zoom/pan controls
   - Collaborative editing

3. **Integration Layer**
   - OAuth management
   - API key storage
   - Connection pooling
   - Rate limiting
   - Error recovery
   - Data transformation

## Feature Components
- **Workflow Designer**
  - Visual canvas
  - Node palette
  - Property inspector
  - Variable manager
  - Test runner
  - Debug console

- **Execution Engine**
  - Queue management
  - Worker pools
  - State persistence
  - Progress tracking
  - Resource allocation
  - Priority handling

- **Template System**
  - Template editor
  - Parameter definition
  - Documentation generator
  - Version comparison
  - Import/export
  - Validation rules

## Integration Catalog
- **Productivity Tools**
  - Slack, Teams, Discord
  - Email (SMTP/IMAP)
  - Calendar systems
  - Task managers

- **Development Tools**
  - GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket
  - CI/CD systems
  - Issue trackers
  - Code review tools

- **Cloud Services**
  - AWS, Azure, GCP
  - Databases
  - Storage systems
  - ML platforms

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Visual builder with 50+ node types
- [ ] Support for 100+ integrations
- [ ] Workflow execution <100ms overhead
- [ ] Parallel execution support
- [ ] 99.9% execution reliability
- [ ] Template marketplace with 200+ templates
- [ ] Real-time execution monitoring
- [ ] Comprehensive error handling
- [ ] Full API for programmatic access

## Performance Requirements
- Execute 10,000+ workflows/minute
- Support workflows with 1000+ nodes
- <50ms node execution overhead
- Real-time status updates
- Horizontal scaling capability

## Priority
**P2** - Important for automation capabilities

## Estimated Effort
6 weeks (4 developers)

## Technical Lead
@Jordan_Kim - Architecture expertise needed

## Related Issues
- Integration with event system
- Requires job queue infrastructure
- Connects with notification system
- Links to monitoring dashboard

comment.body: Sprint 3 Preparation: Architecture design complete. Ready for development start next week. Jordan Kim assigned as lead developer.

issue.title: Runtipi container in crash loop on Ubuntu 24.04 (Contabo VPS) with HestiaCP
issue.body:
Hello,

I'm trying to install Runtipi on a fresh server, but the container is stuck in a restart loop (`Restarting (1)`).

**My Environment:**
*   **OS:** Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
*   **Host:** Contabo VPS
*   **Co-existing Software:** HestiaCP (Nginx as reverse proxy)
*   **Docker Version:** `(mettez ici la sortie de la commande docker --version)`

**My `docker-compose.yml`:**
```yaml
version: "3.8"
services:
  runtipi:
    image: ghcr.io/runtipi/runtipi:latest
    container_name: runtipi
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "127.0.0.1:3000:3000"
    env_file:
      - .env
    volumes:
      - /home/admin/runtipi/data:/app/data
      - /home/admin/runtipi/apps:/app/apps
      - /home/admin/runtipi/backups:/app/backups
      - /home/admin/runtipi/compose:/app/compose
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
```

**My `.env` file:**
```
SERVER_HOSTNAME=localhost
SERVER_PORT=3000
SERVER_SCHEME=http
APPS_DIR=/app/apps
DATA_DIR=/app/data
BACKUPS_DIR=/app/backups
COMPOSE_DIR=/app/compose
ROOT_FOLDER_HOST=/home/admin/runtipi
```

**Docker Logs:**
The logs consistently show the following error:
```
[Nest] 18  - ... ERROR [ExceptionHandler] Error: unable to open database file
...
code: 'ERR_SQLITE_ERROR',
errcode: 14,
errstr: 'unable to open database file'
```

**Troubleshooting Steps Taken:**
*   Set permissions correctly with `sudo chown -R 1000:1000 ~/runtipi`.
*   The container **still crashes even when all volumes are commented out**, which suggests the problem is not a file permission issue on the host.

It seems there might be an incompatibility with the Ubuntu 24.04 environment or a bug in the latest image. Any help would be appreciated.

Thank you!

+		// Read for a short time to verify connection works
+		scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+		scanner.Scan() // Try to read one line (will block until data or context cancellation)
+		
+		resp.Body.Close()
+		connectionDone <- nil
+	}()
+
+	// Wait for connection result
+	select {
+	case err := <-connectionDone:
+		if err != nil {
+			// Context cancellation is expected for SSE connections
+			if !strings.Contains(err.Error(), "context deadline exceeded") {
+				t.Errorf("Unexpected connection error: %v", err)
+			}
+		}
+	case resp := <-respChan:
+		// If we get a response, verify headers
+		require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp.StatusCode)
+		require.Equal(t, "text/event-stream; charset=utf-8", resp.Header.Get("Content-Type"))
+		require.Equal(t, "no-cache", resp.Header.Get("Cache-Control"))
+		resp.Body.Close()
+	case <-time.After(3 * time.Second):
+		t.Error("Connection test timed out")
+	}
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// testAudioLevelSSECleanup tests the audio level SSE handler cleanup
+func testAudioLevelSSECleanup(t *testing.T) {
+	// Create Echo instance
+	e := echo.New()
+	
+	// Create mock handlers with required dependencies
+	handlers := &Handlers{
+		Settings: &conf.Settings{
+			WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{
+				Debug: true,
+			},
+		},
+		debug: true,
+		Server: &mockAccessServer{},
+		AudioLevelChan: make(chan myaudio.AudioLevelData, 10),
+	}
+
+	// Setup route
+	e.GET("/api/v1/audio-level", handlers.AudioLevelSSE)
+	
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+	defer server.Close()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 5 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	// Test connection with context cancellation
+	ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
+	
+	req, err := http.NewRequestWithContext(ctx, "GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/audio-level", nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+	resp, err := client.Do(req)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp.StatusCode)
+
+	// Start reading
+	readDone := make(chan bool, 1)
+	go func() {
+		scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+		for scanner.Scan() {
+			// Read audio level events
+		}
+		readDone <- true
+	}()
+
+	// Send some test audio data
+	go func() {
+		for i := 0; i < 3; i++ {
+			select {
+			case handlers.AudioLevelChan <- myaudio.AudioLevelData{
+				Level:  i * 10,
+				Source: "test-source",
+				Name:   "Test Source",
+			}:
+			case <-time.After(100 * time.Millisecond):
+				return
+			}
+			time.Sleep(50 * time.Millisecond)
+		}
+	}()
+
+	// Wait a bit then cancel context
+	time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
+	cancel()
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	select {
+	case <-readDone:
+		// Expected
+	case <-time.After(1 * time.Second):
+		t.Error("Connection did not close within expected time")
+	}
+
+	resp.Body.Close()
+	close(handlers.AudioLevelChan)
+
+	// Wait for final cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// TestV1SSEConnectionRaceConditions tests that the race condition fixes
+// for connection counting work correctly
+func TestV1SSEConnectionRaceConditions(t *testing.T) {
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+	)
+
+	// Create Echo instance and SSE handler
+	e := echo.New()
+	// Create SSE handler directly instead of using NewSSEHandler() to avoid config dependency
+	sseHandler := &SSEHandler{
+		clients: make(map[chan Notification]bool),
+		debug:   true, // Enable debug for testing
+	}
+	
+	// Setup route
+	e.GET("/api/v1/sse", sseHandler.ServeSSE)
+	
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+	defer server.Close()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 2 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	// Create multiple rapid connections to test race conditions
+	for i := 0; i < 5; i++ {
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/sse", nil)
+		require.NoError(t, err)
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue // May timeout, which is fine
+		}
+
+		// Immediately close to stress test the cleanup logic
+		resp.Body.Close()
+
+		// Small delay between requests
+		time.Sleep(20 * time.Millisecond)
+	}
+
+	// Wait for all cleanup
+	time.Sleep(500 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// TestV1AudioLevelSSEDuplicateConnections tests that duplicate connection
+// prevention works correctly
+func TestV1AudioLevelSSEDuplicateConnections(t *testing.T) {
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+	)
+
+	// Create Echo instance
+	e := echo.New()
+	
+	handlers := &Handlers{
+		Settings: &conf.Settings{
+			WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{Debug: true},
+		},
+		debug: true,
+		Server: &mockAccessServer{},
+		AudioLevelChan: make(chan myaudio.AudioLevelData, 10),
+	}
+
+	e.GET("/api/v1/audio-level", handlers.AudioLevelSSE)
+	
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer close(handlers.AudioLevelChan)
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 2 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	// Make first connection
+	req1, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/audio-level", nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req1.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+	req1.Header.Set("X-Forwarded-For", "192.168.1.100") // Set specific IP
+
+	resp1, err := client.Do(req1)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp1.StatusCode)
+
+	// Make second connection from same IP (should be rejected)
+	req2, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/audio-level", nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req2.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+	req2.Header.Set("X-Forwarded-For", "192.168.1.100") // Same IP
+
+	resp2, err := client.Do(req2)
+	if err == nil {
+		// If no error, should be rejected with 429
+		require.Equal(t, http.StatusTooManyRequests, resp2.StatusCode)
+		resp2.Body.Close()
+	}
+
+	resp1.Body.Close()
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// mockAccessServer implements the minimal interface needed for testing
+type mockAccessServer struct{}
+
+func (m *mockAccessServer) IsAccessAllowed(c echo.Context) bool {
+	return true // Always allow access for testing
+}
+
+func (m *mockAccessServer) GetProcessor() serviceapi.BirdNETProvider {
+	return mockBirdNETProvider{}
+}
+
+// mockBirdNETProvider implements serviceapi.BirdNETProvider for testing
+type mockBirdNETProvider struct{}
+
+func (m mockBirdNETProvider) GetBirdNET() *birdnet.BirdNET {
+	return nil // Return nil for testing
+}
+
+// BenchmarkV1SSEConnection benchmarks v1 SSE connection performance
+func BenchmarkV1SSEConnection(b *testing.B) {
+	e := echo.New()
+	// Create SSE handler directly instead of using NewSSEHandler() to avoid config dependency
+	sseHandler := &SSEHandler{
+		clients: make(map[chan Notification]bool),
+		debug:   false, // Disable debug for benchmarking
+	}
+	e.GET("/api/v1/sse", sseHandler.ServeSSE)
+	
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+	defer server.Close()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	b.ResetTimer()
+
+	for i := 0; i < b.N; i++ {
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/sse", nil)
+		if err != nil {
+			b.Fatal(err)
+		}
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue
+		}
+
+		// Read briefly then close
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+			if scanner.Scan() {
+				// Read one line
+			}
+		}
+
+		resp.Body.Close()
+	}
+}

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming endpoints, validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness and reliability verification.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

Line 133 contains a time comparison that will always be false: `time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now())` compares a past time with the current time, which can never be true.


Apply this diff to fix the timeout logic:

+	startTime := time.Now()

-		if time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now()) {

+// sse_connection_test.go: Tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
+// This test suite prevents regression of the critical memory leak issues fixed in PR #1163
+
+package api
+
+import (
+	"bufio"
+	"context"
+	"fmt"
+	"net/http"
+	"net/http/httptest"
+	"strings"
+	"sync"
+	"testing"
+	"time"
+
+	"github.com/labstack/echo/v4"
+	"github.com/stretchr/testify/require"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/birdnet"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/conf"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/observability"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/serviceapi"
+	"go.uber.org/goleak"
+)
+
+// SSETestConfig holds configuration for SSE connection tests
+type SSETestConfig struct {
+	endpoint          string
+	maxConnections    int
+	testTimeout       time.Duration
+	connectionTimeout time.Duration
+}
+
+// Common test configurations for different SSE endpoints
+var sseTestConfigs = []SSETestConfig{
+	// Note: /notifications/stream endpoint requires authentication and is tested separately
+	{
+		endpoint:          "/detections/stream", 
+		maxConnections:    3,
+		testTimeout:       5 * time.Second,
+		connectionTimeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	},
+	{
+		endpoint:          "/soundlevels/stream",
+		maxConnections:    3,
+		testTimeout:       5 * time.Second,
+		connectionTimeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	},
+}
+
+// TestSSEConnectionCleanup is the main test that verifies SSE connections
+// are properly cleaned up without goroutine leaks
+func TestSSEConnectionCleanup(t *testing.T) {
+	// Defer goleak check to verify no goroutines leak after test
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		// Ignore goroutines from testing framework and other standard libraries
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		// Ignore the go-cache janitor which we can't control
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		// Ignore lumberjack logger goroutines
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	for _, config := range sseTestConfigs {
+		config := config // Capture loop variable
+		t.Run(fmt.Sprintf("endpoint_%s", strings.ReplaceAll(config.endpoint, "/", "_")), func(t *testing.T) {
+			t.Parallel()
+			testSSEEndpointCleanup(t, config)
+		})
+	}
+}
+
+// testSSEEndpointCleanup tests a specific SSE endpoint for proper cleanup
+func testSSEEndpointCleanup(t *testing.T, config SSETestConfig) {
+	// Create test server
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServer(t)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	t.Run("single_connection_manual_disconnect", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect(t, server, config)
+	})
+
+	t.Run("single_connection_context_cancellation", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testSingleConnectionContextCancellation(t, server, config)
+	})
+
+	t.Run("multiple_concurrent_connections", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testMultipleConcurrentConnections(t, server, config)
+	})
+
+	t.Run("connection_timeout", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testConnectionTimeout(t, server, config)
+	})
+}
+
+// testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect verifies that manually closing an SSE connection
+// properly cleans up goroutines
+func testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	// Create HTTP client
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: config.testTimeout,
+	}
+
+	// Make SSE request
+	req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2"+config.endpoint, nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+	req.Header.Set("Cache-Control", "no-cache")
+
+	resp, err := client.Do(req)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp.StatusCode)
+
+	// Verify SSE headers
+	require.Equal(t, "text/event-stream", resp.Header.Get("Content-Type"))
+	require.Equal(t, "no-cache", resp.Header.Get("Cache-Control"))
+
+	// Read first event (connection established)
+	scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+	connected := false
+	for scanner.Scan() {
+		line := scanner.Text()
+		if strings.Contains(line, "connected") || strings.Contains(line, "Connected") {
+			connected = true
+			break
+		}
+		// Don't wait too long for connection event
+		if time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now()) {
+			break
+		}
+	}
+	require.True(t, connected, "Should receive connection event")
+
+	// Close connection manually
+	resp.Body.Close()
+
+	// Wait briefly for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
+
+	// Connection should be cleaned up - no way to verify directly in this context
+	// but goleak will catch any leaked goroutines
+}
+
+// testSingleConnectionContextCancellation verifies that canceling the context
+// properly cleans up the SSE connection
+func testSingleConnectionContextCancellation(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	// Create context with cancellation
+	ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
+
+	// Create HTTP client with context
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: config.testTimeout,
+	}
+
+	// Make SSE request with context
+	req, err := http.NewRequestWithContext(ctx, "GET", server.URL+"/api/v2"+config.endpoint, nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")

+	controlChan := make(chan string, 10)
+

+	mockMetrics, _ := observability.NewMetrics()
+
+	// Create controller WITH route initialization
+	controller, err := NewWithOptions(e, mockDS, settings, nil, nil, controlChan, nil, nil, mockMetrics, true)
+	require.NoError(t, err)

+	// Wait for goroutines to start
+	if controller.goroutinesStarted != nil {
+		select {
+		case <-controller.goroutinesStarted:
+			// Controller is ready
+		case <-time.After(2 * time.Second):
+			t.Fatal("Controller failed to start within timeout")
+		}
+	}
+
+	// Create test server
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+
+	return server, controller
+}
+
+// Benchmark for SSE connection performance
+func BenchmarkSSEConnectionSetup(b *testing.B) {
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServerForBench(b)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 5 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	b.ResetTimer()
+	
+	for i := 0; i < b.N; i++ {
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2/notifications/stream", nil)
+		if err != nil {
+			b.Fatal(err)
+		}
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue // Rate limiting may occur
+		}
+
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			// Read one event then close
+			scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+			if scanner.Scan() {
+				// Got one event
+			}
+		}
+
+		resp.Body.Close()
+	}
+}
+
+// setupSSETestServerForBench creates a test server for benchmarking
+func setupSSETestServerForBench(b *testing.B) (*httptest.Server, *Controller) {
+	e := echo.New()
+	mockDS := new(MockDataStore)
+	settings := &conf.Settings{
+		WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{Debug: false}, // Disable debug for benchmarking
+		Realtime: conf.RealtimeSettings{
+			Audio: conf.AudioSettings{
+				Export: conf.ExportSettings{Path: b.TempDir()},
+			},
+		},
+	}
+	controlChan := make(chan string, 10)
+	mockMetrics, _ := observability.NewMetrics()
+
+	controller, err := NewWithOptions(e, mockDS, settings, nil, nil, controlChan, nil, nil, mockMetrics, true)
+	if err != nil {
+		b.Fatal(err)
+	}
+
+	if controller.goroutinesStarted != nil {
+		<-controller.goroutinesStarted
+	}
+
+	return httptest.NewServer(e), controller
+}

Would you like me to help refactor this to extract common server setup logic into a shared helper function that both `setupSSETestServer` and `setupSSETestServerForBench` can use?

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming endpoints, validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness and reliability verification.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

+// TestSSERateLimiting verifies that SSE rate limiting works correctly
+// and doesn't cause goroutine leaks
+func TestSSERateLimiting(t *testing.T) {
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServer(t)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 2 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	var successCount, rateLimitedCount int
+
+	// Make many rapid requests to trigger rate limiting
+	for i := 0; i < 15; i++ { // More than the rate limit of 10
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2/detections/stream", nil)
+		require.NoError(t, err)
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue
+		}
+
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			successCount++
+		} else if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusTooManyRequests {
+			rateLimitedCount++
+		}
+
+		resp.Body.Close()
+	}
+
+	// Should have some successful connections and some rate limited
+	require.Greater(t, successCount, 0, "Should have some successful connections")
+	require.Greater(t, rateLimitedCount, 0, "Should have some rate limited connections")
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// setupSSETestServer creates a test server with SSE endpoints configured
+func setupSSETestServer(t *testing.T) (*httptest.Server, *Controller) {
+	// Create Echo instance
+	e := echo.New()
+
+	// Create mock datastore
+	mockDS := new(MockDataStore)
+
+	// Create settings with required paths
+	settings := &conf.Settings{
+		WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{
+			Debug: true,
+		},
+		Realtime: conf.RealtimeSettings{
+			Audio: conf.AudioSettings{
+				Export: conf.ExportSettings{
+					Path: t.TempDir(),
+				},
+			},
+		},
+	}
+
+	// Create control channel
+	controlChan := make(chan string, 10)
+
+	// Create mock metrics
+	mockMetrics, _ := observability.NewMetrics()
+
+	// Create controller WITH route initialization
+	controller, err := NewWithOptions(e, mockDS, settings, nil, nil, controlChan, nil, nil, mockMetrics, true)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+
+	// Wait for goroutines to start
+	if controller.goroutinesStarted != nil {
+		select {
+		case <-controller.goroutinesStarted:
+			// Controller is ready
+		case <-time.After(2 * time.Second):
+			t.Fatal("Controller failed to start within timeout")
+		}
+	}
+
+	// Create test server
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+
+	return server, controller
+}
+
+// Benchmark for SSE connection performance
+func BenchmarkSSEConnectionSetup(b *testing.B) {
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServerForBench(b)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 5 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	b.ResetTimer()
+	
+	for i := 0; i < b.N; i++ {
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2/notifications/stream", nil)
+		if err != nil {
+			b.Fatal(err)
+		}
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue // Rate limiting may occur
+		}
+
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			// Read one event then close
+			scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+			if scanner.Scan() {
+				// Got one event
+			}
+		}
+
+		resp.Body.Close()
+	}
+}

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming endpoints, validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness and reliability verification.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

_âš ï¸ Potential issue_

**Fix incorrect timeout check in connection test.**

The timeout logic at line 133 is incorrect: `time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now())` will always be false since a past time cannot be after the current time.


Apply this diff to fix the timeout logic:
```diff
 	// Read first event (connection established)
 	scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
 	connected := false
+	startTime := time.Now()
 	for scanner.Scan() {
 		line := scanner.Text()
 		if strings.Contains(line, "connected") || strings.Contains(line, "Connected") {
 			connected = true
 			break
 		}
 		// Don't wait too long for connection event
-		if time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now()) {
+		if time.Since(startTime) > time.Second {
 			break
 		}
 	}
```

> â€¼ï¸ **IMPORTANT**

```suggestion
    // Read first event (connection established)
    scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
    connected := false
    startTime := time.Now()
    for scanner.Scan() {
        line := scanner.Text()
        if strings.Contains(line, "connected") || strings.Contains(line, "Connected") {
            connected = true
            break
        }

        if time.Since(startTime) > time.Second {

```

In internal/api/v2/sse_connection_test.go around lines 125 to 137, the timeout
check inside the scanner loop is wrong
(time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now()) is always false); fix it by
capturing a start time before the loop (start := time.Now()) and replace the
faulty check with a proper deadline or elapsed check such as if
time.Since(start) > time.Second { break }, so the loop stops after one second if
no connection event is received.

`117-124`: **Remove unused networks_json or put it to use** ShellCheck correctly points out networks_json is computed but not used. Apply this diff to remove dead code: ```diff -# Convert platform list to JSON array -networks_json=$(jq -n --argjson p "$(printf '%s\n' "${networks_list[@]}" | jq -R . | jq -s .)" '$p') -# Final merged matrix +# Final merged matrix matrix_final="[]" ``` --- `126-126`: **Quote variable in source to avoid word-splitting** While net values are trimmed, quoting is a safe default for robustness. ```diff - source ../multinet_envs.sh ${net} + source ../multinet_envs.sh "${net}" ``` --- `10-10`: **Avoid leaking set -euxo pipefail to parent shell when sourced** This script is sourced by the workflow step to populate matrix in the callerâ€™s shell. set -euxo pipefail at top-level will propagate to the parent shell, making subsequent commands verbose and potentially fail on unset vars. Gate it so it only applies when the script is executed directly, not sourced. ```diff -set -euxo pipefail +if [[ "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" == "${0}" ]]; then + set -euxo pipefail +fi ``` If you prefer, we can also switch the workflow to capture the matrix from a subshell to avoid side effects.
.github/workflows/build_dockers_workflow.yml (3)
`303-303`: **Fix typo in log message** Minor typo in user-visible output. ```diff - echo "Latest Alis Multi-Arch tag - ${{ inputs.tag_alias }}" + echo "Latest Alias Multi-Arch tag - ${{ inputs.tag_alias }}" ``` --- `76-76`: **Optional: avoid sourcing side-effects by capturing matrix in a subshell** Because build-matrix.sh sets shell options when sourced, consider isolating it. Not required if you gate set -euxo pipefail in the script, but this is another safe approach. For example: ```bash # replace the source invocation with: matrix="$( bash -lc 'source ./build-matrix.sh "'"${{ inputs.build_items }}"'" "'"${VERSION}"'" "'"${{ inputs.platforms }}"'" "'"${{ inputs.tari_network }}"'"; printf "%s" "$matrix"' )" ``` Iâ€™m happy to provide a cleaner emit-only mode for the script if you prefer. --- `282-287`: **Consider using the configured provider instead of hardcoding quay.io** You already parameterize the provider via secrets.DOCKER_PROVIDER elsewhere. Using it here keeps both registries aligned without assuming quay.io. ```diff - for DREGISTRY in ghcr.io quay.io; do + for DREGISTRY in ghcr.io ${{ secrets.DOCKER_PROVIDER }}; do ```

+	{
+		endpoint:          "/soundlevels/stream",
+		maxConnections:    3,
+		testTimeout:       5 * time.Second,
+		connectionTimeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	},
+}
+
+// TestSSEConnectionCleanup is the main test that verifies SSE connections
+// are properly cleaned up without goroutine leaks
+func TestSSEConnectionCleanup(t *testing.T) {
+	// Defer goleak check to verify no goroutines leak after test
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		// Ignore goroutines from testing framework and other standard libraries
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		// Ignore the go-cache janitor which we can't control
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		// Ignore lumberjack logger goroutines
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	for _, config := range sseTestConfigs {
+		config := config // Capture loop variable
+		t.Run(fmt.Sprintf("endpoint_%s", strings.ReplaceAll(config.endpoint, "/", "_")), func(t *testing.T) {
+			t.Parallel()
+			testSSEEndpointCleanup(t, config)
+		})
+	}
+}
+
+// testSSEEndpointCleanup tests a specific SSE endpoint for proper cleanup
+func testSSEEndpointCleanup(t *testing.T, config SSETestConfig) {
+	// Create test server
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServer(t)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	t.Run("single_connection_manual_disconnect", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect(t, server, config)
+	})
+
+	t.Run("single_connection_context_cancellation", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testSingleConnectionContextCancellation(t, server, config)
+	})
+
+	t.Run("multiple_concurrent_connections", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testMultipleConcurrentConnections(t, server, config)
+	})
+
+	t.Run("connection_timeout", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testConnectionTimeout(t, server, config)
+	})
+}
+
+// testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect verifies that manually closing an SSE connection
+// properly cleans up goroutines
+func testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	// Create HTTP client
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: config.testTimeout,
+	}
+
+	// Make SSE request
+	req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2"+config.endpoint, nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+	req.Header.Set("Cache-Control", "no-cache")
+
+	resp, err := client.Do(req)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp.StatusCode)
+
+	// Verify SSE headers
+	require.Equal(t, "text/event-stream", resp.Header.Get("Content-Type"))
+	require.Equal(t, "no-cache", resp.Header.Get("Cache-Control"))
+
+	// Read first event (connection established)
+	scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+	connected := false
+	for scanner.Scan() {
+		line := scanner.Text()
+		if strings.Contains(line, "connected") || strings.Contains(line, "Connected") {
+			connected = true
+			break
+		}
+		// Don't wait too long for connection event
+		if time.Now().Add(-time.Second).After(time.Now()) {
+			break
+		}
+	}
+	require.True(t, connected, "Should receive connection event")
+
+	// Close connection manually
+	resp.Body.Close()
+
+	// Wait briefly for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
+
+	// Connection should be cleaned up - no way to verify directly in this context
+	// but goleak will catch any leaked goroutines
+}
+
+// testSingleConnectionContextCancellation verifies that canceling the context
+// properly cleans up the SSE connection
+func testSingleConnectionContextCancellation(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	// Create context with cancellation
+	ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
+
+	// Create HTTP client with context
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: config.testTimeout,
+	}
+
+	// Make SSE request with context
+	req, err := http.NewRequestWithContext(ctx, "GET", server.URL+"/api/v2"+config.endpoint, nil)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+	resp, err := client.Do(req)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp.StatusCode)
+
+	// Start reading in goroutine
+	done := make(chan bool, 1)
+	go func() {
+		scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+		for scanner.Scan() {
+			// Just read events until context cancellation
+		}
+		done <- true
+	}()
+
+	// Wait a bit to establish connection
+	time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
+
+	// Cancel context
+	cancel()
+
+	// Wait for goroutine to finish
+	select {
+	case <-done:
+		// Expected - connection should close due to context cancellation
+	case <-time.After(500 * time.Millisecond):
+		t.Error("Connection did not close within expected time after context cancellation")
+	}
+
+	resp.Body.Close()
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// testMultipleConcurrentConnections verifies that multiple concurrent SSE connections
+// are all properly cleaned up
+func testMultipleConcurrentConnections(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	var wg sync.WaitGroup
+	var connectionsEstablished int32
+
+	// Start multiple concurrent connections
+	for i := 0; i < config.maxConnections; i++ {
+		wg.Add(1)
+		go func(connID int) {
+			defer wg.Done()
+
+			client := &http.Client{
+				Timeout: config.testTimeout,
+			}
+
+			req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2"+config.endpoint, nil)
+			if err != nil {
+				t.Errorf("Connection %d: Failed to create request: %v", connID, err)
+				return
+			}
+			req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+			resp, err := client.Do(req)
+			if err != nil {
+				// May fail due to rate limiting, which is acceptable
+				return
+			}
+			defer resp.Body.Close()
+
+			if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+				connectionsEstablished++
+				
+				// Read a few events
+				scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+				eventCount := 0
+				for scanner.Scan() && eventCount < 3 {
+					eventCount++
+				}
+			}
+		}(i)
+	}
+
+	// Wait for all connections to complete
+	wg.Wait()
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+
+	// At least one connection should have been established
+	require.Greater(t, int(connectionsEstablished), 0, 
+		"At least one connection should have been established")
+}

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming endpoints, validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness and reliability verification.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

review.body:
**Actionable comments posted: 3**
ğŸ”­ Outside diff range comments (4)
cratis-core/src/config.rs (2)
`141-170`: **Docs for update_config are stale after signature change** The examples and argument list donâ€™t mention the new config_path parameter and show the old two-arg call site. Update the docs to include config_path in examples and arguments. Suggested example update: ```rust /// let new_addr = Value::String("0.0.0.0:9000".to_string()); /// update_config("server.address", "/path/to/config.yml", new_addr)?; ``` --- `192-201`: **Bug: creating missing nested keys inserts Null, causing recursion to fail** When an intermediate key is missing, you insert Value::Null and recurse, which will immediately error because Null is not a Mapping. Replace with a Mapping for intermediate nodes; only set the leaf directly. ```diff Value::Mapping(map) => { let key = Value::String(keys[0].to_string()); if let Some(v) = map.get_mut(&key) { update_recursive(v, &keys[1..], new_value) } else { - // If key doesn't exist, create it - map.insert(key.clone(), Value::Null); - update_recursive(map.get_mut(&key).unwrap(), &keys[1..], new_value) + // If key doesn't exist, create nested mappings as needed + if keys.len() == 1 { + map.insert(key.clone(), new_value); + Ok(()) + } else { + map.insert(key.clone(), Value::Mapping(Default::default())); + update_recursive(map.get_mut(&key).unwrap(), &keys[1..], new_value) + } } }, ```
cratis-core/src/utils.rs (1)
`281-294`: **Borrowed temporary bug: referencing a cloned temporary Vec** Youâ€™re taking a reference to a temporary created by clone().unwrap_or_default(), which will not live long enough and should not compile. Own the Vec instead. Apply: ```diff - let config: &CratisConfig = crate::config::get_config_cli(); - - let exclude_dirs: &Vec = &config.backup.exclude.clone().unwrap_or_default(); + let config: &CratisConfig = crate::config::get_config_cli(); + let exclude_dirs: Vec = config.backup.exclude.clone().unwrap_or_default(); let mut exclude_patterns: Vec = Vec::new(); - if !exclude_dirs.is_empty() { - for pattern in exclude_dirs.iter() { + if !exclude_dirs.is_empty() { + for pattern in exclude_dirs.iter() { match Pattern::new(pattern) { Ok(p) => exclude_patterns.push(p), Err(e) => display_msg(Some(&CratisError::ConfigError(format!("Invalid exclusion pattern '{}': {}", pattern, e))), CratisErrorLevel::Fatal, None) } } } ```
cratis-cli/src/main.rs (1)
`32-35`: **Fix use-after-move and unnecessary unwrap in match on backup_now()** result is moved into the match; referencing result.unwrap() inside the Ok arm is a use-after-move and will fail to compile. Match the awaited result directly and use the bound value. ```diff - let result: CratisResult = backup_now().await; - match result { - Ok(_) => display_msg(None, CratisErrorLevel::Info, Some(result.unwrap())), - Err(e) => display_msg(Some(&e), CratisErrorLevel::Warning, None), - } + match backup_now().await { + Ok(msg) => display_msg(None, CratisErrorLevel::Info, Some(msg)), + Err(e) => display_msg(Some(&e), CratisErrorLevel::Warning, None), + } ```
ğŸ§¹ Nitpick comments (15)
cratis-core/src/error.rs (1)
`93-94`: **Consider avoiding std::process::exit in a core library function** Exiting the process from core makes callers (CLI/API) harder to test and recover. Consider returning a Result or delegating fatal handling to the caller instead.
cratis-core/src/config.rs (4)
`10-11`: **Avoid absolute, user-specific TEMP paths** Hardcoding an absolute development path makes builds non-portable. Prefer one of: - Environment-variable override with a sensible default. - XDG config directory resolution (e.g., $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/cratis/...). - Relative paths in workspace for dev builds behind a feature flag. ```diff -pub static TEMP_API_CONFIG_PATH: &str = "/home/raphael/Development/Cratis/cratis-api/config.yml"; +pub static TEMP_API_CONFIG_PATH: &str = "cratis-api/config.yml"; // TODO: load from env/XDG ``` --- `95-116`: **Simplify get_config_cli; unreachable branch is not needed** With load_config handling failure via display_msg + exit, you can simplify control flow. ```diff pub fn get_config_cli() -> &'static CratisConfig { - if CONFIG_CLI.get().is_none() { - load_config(TEMP_CONFIG_PATH, false); - - if CONFIG_CLI.get().is_none() { - display_msg(Some(&CratisError::ConfigError("Unable to load config".to_string())), CratisErrorLevel::Fatal, None); - unreachable!() - } else { - CONFIG_CLI.get().unwrap() - } - } else { - CONFIG_CLI.get().unwrap() - } + if CONFIG_CLI.get().is_none() { + load_config(TEMP_CONFIG_PATH, false); + } + CONFIG_CLI.get().expect("CLI config must be initialized by load_config()") } ``` --- `118-139`: **Mirror the same simplification in get_config_api** Same rationale as for CLI. ```diff pub fn get_config_api() -> &'static CratisServerConfig { - if CONFIG_API.get().is_none() { - load_config(TEMP_API_CONFIG_PATH, true); - - if CONFIG_API.get().is_none() { - display_msg(Some(&CratisError::ConfigError("Unable to load config".to_string())), CratisErrorLevel::Fatal, None); - unreachable!() - } else { - CONFIG_API.get().unwrap() - } - } else { - CONFIG_API.get().unwrap() - } + if CONFIG_API.get().is_none() { + load_config(TEMP_API_CONFIG_PATH, true); + } + CONFIG_API.get().expect("API config must be initialized by load_config()") } ``` --- `71-92`: **Note: Config updates donâ€™t refresh in-memory OnceCell caches** After update_config writes to disk, CONFIG_CLI/CONFIG_API are not reloaded (OnceCell cannot be set twice). Consider providing a reload_config or switching to Lazy with RwLock for live reloads, if hot-reload is desired.
cratis-cli/src/cli.rs (1)
`168-172`: **Make API endpoint and token configurable (from config)** Hardcoded API URL and test token will block real usage. You already have server.address and auth_token in CratisConfig::server; wire them in. ```diff - let api_url = "http://localhost:8080/upload"; // TODO: Make this configurable - let auth_token = "test"; // TODO: Load it from config, write auth token generator + let api_url = format!("{}/upload", config.server.address.trim_end_matches('/')); + let auth_token = &config.server.auth_token; ```
cratis-api/src/handler/authentication.rs (3)
`193-199`: **Avoid cloning the JWT secret unnecessarily** You can borrow the secret and use as_bytes() to avoid allocating a String. ```diff - let secret: String = get_config_api().settings.jwt.clone(); + let secret: &str = get_config_api().settings.jwt.as_str(); - if secret.is_empty() { + if secret.is_empty() { display_msg(Some(&CratisError::TokenError("JWT Secret is empty!".to_string())), CratisErrorLevel::Warning, None); return None } - let encoding_key: EncodingKey = EncodingKey::from_secret(secret.as_bytes()); + let encoding_key: EncodingKey = EncodingKey::from_secret(secret.as_bytes()); ``` --- `200-209`: **Consider adding exp to JWT claims and validating it** Tokens never expire (validation.validate_exp = false and no exp in claims). For better security, add an exp claim and validate it. Example: ```rust #[derive(Debug, Serialize, Deserialize, Clone)] struct Claims { device_id: String, exp: usize, // seconds since epoch } // In generate_jwt: let exp = (std::time::SystemTime::now() + std::time::Duration::from_secs(3600)) .duration_since(std::time::UNIX_EPOCH).unwrap().as_secs() as usize; let claims = Claims { device_id, exp }; // In decode_token: let mut validation = Validation::new(Algorithm::HS256); validation.validate_exp = true; ``` --- `212-217`: **Same nit: borrow secret in decode_token** Mirror the borrowing change and keep the empty-secret guard. ```diff - let secret: String = get_config_api().settings.jwt.clone(); + let secret: &str = get_config_api().settings.jwt.as_str(); if secret.is_empty() { display_msg(Some(&CratisError::TokenError("JWT Secret is empty!".to_string())), CratisErrorLevel::Warning, None); return Err(jsonwebtoken::errors::Error::from(jsonwebtoken::errors::ErrorKind::InvalidKeyFormat)); } ```
cratis-api/src/main.rs (4)
`18-20`: **Avoid eager config load; rely on get_config_api or handle errors consistently** get_config_api() already lazy-loads the API config. Calling load_config here is redundant and uses expect(), which panics rather than following your display_msg-based error handling. Recommend removing this eager load to avoid duplication and inconsistency. ```diff - // Load config - load_config(TEMP_API_CONFIG_PATH, true); ``` --- `14-14`: **Prefer injecting DB via Axum State over a global static** A global Lazy> works, but pushing DB via Router::with_state and axum::extract::State improves testability, modularity, and reduces tight coupling. Consider moving to app state when convenient (will require minor handler adjustments). --- `35-36`: **Handle bind/serve errors explicitly; avoid unwraps and use SocketAddr for clarity** Unwrap will panic without context. Since you already have a display/error system, report failures and exit gracefully. Also, building the address via SocketAddr is more idiomatic and type-safe than formatting a string. ```diff - let listener = tokio::net::TcpListener::bind(format!("0.0.0.0:{}", get_config_api().settings.port)).await.unwrap(); - axum::serve(listener, app).await.unwrap(); + let port = get_config_api().settings.port; + let addr = std::net::SocketAddr::from(([0, 0, 0, 0], port)); + let listener = tokio::net::TcpListener::bind(addr).await.unwrap_or_else(|e| { + display_msg(Some(&CratisError::ConfigError(format!("Failed to bind on {addr}: {e}"))), CratisErrorLevel::Fatal, None); + unreachable!() + }); + if let Err(e) = axum::serve(listener, app).await { + display_msg(Some(&CratisError::ConfigError(format!("Server error: {e}"))), CratisErrorLevel::Fatal, None); + } ``` --- `1-3`: **Cleanup: remove unused imports and the unused_imports allowance once settled** middleware and the error imports are currently unused (commented code). Consider removing #[allow(unused_imports)] and unused imports when the routes/auth layer stabilizes. Also applies to: 9-9
cratis-cli/src/main.rs (2)
`11-11`: **load_config panics on missing/invalid config; consider graceful handling** load_config() uses expect() internally, so a missing or invalid TEMP_CONFIG_PATH will panic. For a CLI UX, consider changing cratis-core::config::load_config to return a Result and handle it here with display_msg, or preflight-check the file and create a default if absent. --- `21-21`: **Config update call looks correct; verify key path aligns with CLI config schema** Passing the path explicitly is a nice improvement. Ensure server.auth_token belongs to the CLI config file structure to avoid creating unexpected keys.

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming endpoints, validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness and reliability verification.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

review.body:
**Actionable comments posted: 4**
ğŸ§¹ Nitpick comments (6)
buildtools/docker_rig/build-matrix.sh (3)
`117-124`: **Remove unused networks_json or put it to use** ShellCheck correctly points out networks_json is computed but not used. Apply this diff to remove dead code: ```diff -# Convert platform list to JSON array -networks_json=$(jq -n --argjson p "$(printf '%s\n' "${networks_list[@]}" | jq -R . | jq -s .)" '$p') -# Final merged matrix +# Final merged matrix matrix_final="[]" ``` --- `126-126`: **Quote variable in source to avoid word-splitting** While net values are trimmed, quoting is a safe default for robustness. ```diff - source ../multinet_envs.sh ${net} + source ../multinet_envs.sh "${net}" ``` --- `10-10`: **Avoid leaking set -euxo pipefail to parent shell when sourced** This script is sourced by the workflow step to populate matrix in the callerâ€™s shell. set -euxo pipefail at top-level will propagate to the parent shell, making subsequent commands verbose and potentially fail on unset vars. Gate it so it only applies when the script is executed directly, not sourced. ```diff -set -euxo pipefail +if [[ "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" == "${0}" ]]; then + set -euxo pipefail +fi ``` If you prefer, we can also switch the workflow to capture the matrix from a subshell to avoid side effects.
.github/workflows/build_dockers_workflow.yml (3)
`303-303`: **Fix typo in log message** Minor typo in user-visible output. ```diff - echo "Latest Alis Multi-Arch tag - ${{ inputs.tag_alias }}" + echo "Latest Alias Multi-Arch tag - ${{ inputs.tag_alias }}" ``` --- `76-76`: **Optional: avoid sourcing side-effects by capturing matrix in a subshell** Because build-matrix.sh sets shell options when sourced, consider isolating it. Not required if you gate set -euxo pipefail in the script, but this is another safe approach. ## Summary by CodeRabbit

* **New Features**
  * Docker images are now network-aware with clear, network-specific tags.
  * Multi-arch manifests are published per network, improving pulls on different platforms.

* **Chores**
  * Build pipeline now includes per-network entries in the matrix for consistent tagging and packaging.
  * Removed legacy global network env usage in favor of matrix-driven values.
  * Streamlined tagging logic and manifest grouping by network.
  * Enabled verbose shell in a prep step to aid troubleshooting.
